message_1: Consider a topological space $X$ such that its cohomology group $H^1(X)$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2$ (the group of integers modulo 2). Find the number of connected components of $X$.
message_2:
Since $H^1(X)$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2$, this means that $H^1(X)$ has only one non-trivial element (besides the identity element). Recall that the first cohomology group $H^1(X)$ is related to the number of connected components of the topological space $X$.

In particular, the rank of $H^0(X)$, which is the zeroth cohomology group, corresponds to the number of connected components of $X$. The zeroth cohomology group $H^0(X)$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}^n$, where $n$ is the number of connected components of $X$.

Now, we use the Universal Coefficient Theorem for cohomology, which states that there is a short exact sequence:

$0 \to \text{Ext}^1(H_{k-1}(X), G) \to H^k(X, G) \to \text{Hom}(H_k(X), G) \to 0$

Here, $G$ is a coefficient group, and in our case, we have $G = \mathbb{Z}$. We are interested in the case when $k=1$. So, we have:

$0 \to \text{Ext}^1(H_0(X), \mathbb{Z}) \to H^1(X, \mathbb{Z}) \to \text{Hom}(H_1(X), \mathbb{Z}) \to 0$

Since $H^1(X)$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2$, we know that $H^1(X, \mathbb{Z})$ has only one non-trivial element. Moreover, we know that $\text{Hom}(H_1(X), \mathbb{Z})$ is a free abelian group, and thus, it has no non-trivial torsion elements. This implies that the non-trivial element in $H^1(X, \mathbb{Z})$ must come from $\text{Ext}^1(H_0(X), \mathbb{Z})$.

Now, we use the fact that $\text{Ext}^1(\mathbb{Z}^n, \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}_2^{n-1}$, which means that $\text{Ext}^1(H_0(X), \mathbb{Z})$ has $2^{n-1}$ non-trivial elements. Since we have only one non-trivial element in $H^1(X, \mathbb{Z})$, we must have:

$2^{n-1} = 1$

Solving for $n$, we get $n-1 = 0$, which implies that $n = 1$. Therefore, the topological space $X$ has only one connected component.
